hi and welcome you listening to the ex
when he to report my name is Dave and
this is episode 1547 a and today's date
is April 17th 2018 and the title of the
episode is was this part of the plan
dumped Treasuries to destroy the central
bank economy let's get into the economic
collapse financial news now the central
bankers they they are making it very
very clear that they're not going to
keep this economy going forever because
there are many different reports coming
out especially from the IMF where
they're discussing how the economy looks
good now but that is going to change and
we'll discuss that in just a minute but
let's get into what is happening here in
the retail market now we had a report
that came out last week and they're
saying that bankruptcies in the retail
sector they're at a record high during
the first quarter of 2018 and this
report which is done by Moody's confirms
that yes
bankruptcies in the retail sectors were
at a record high during the first
quarter of 2018 they were nine defaults
in the sector including Sears and clears
during the three months and then ending
in March 31st tops friendly markets
supermarket chain and the bond town
department store chain also filed for
bankruptcy during this period defaults
on corporate debt from the retail sector
in the past three months made up almost
one-third of default by corporations in
all industries and what we're seeing
right now is that things are getting
actually worse as time goes on now again
tops friendly markets that's a
supermarket chain and many people don't
buy their food over the Internet and
what we're seeing right now is that
traffic is drying up at the malls
traffic at stores they are driving
drying up and a lot of people are saying
you know what I just don't have the
funds to go out and to purchase like I
used to
now there was a time and we need to
remember how this all works there was a
time in the beginning of this fayed
system back in 1970s where everything
was just beginning
there was really no credit most of the
people back then only had maybe gas
cards they really didn't have the credit
cards that we see today one of the first
was like mastercharge it wasn't even
called MasterCard a lot of people had
diners club and what has happened over
the period of time as credit as the
printing of money continued and the
devaluation of the dollar you had to
move into a credit cycle and this is
what we've been in for a very long time
where credit basically took over from
people having the actual cash to go out
and spend now at the end of this system
what happens well people are up to their
eyeballs in debt now think about it go
back to the 80s because in the 70s were
coming off the gold standard moving on
to the petro dollar system where there
was a lot of inflation a lot of dollars
being printed the value of the dollar
was decreasing so we saw salaries move
up because of inflation we saw a housing
move up and in the 80s all of a sudden
at that point they were able to reduce
the interest rates once that happened
they introduced credit cards they
introduced a lot of different things and
people were going out spending like
crazy because they were spending money
they really didn't have and that was
like the 80s where you had this credit
boom cycle and that was moving into the
90s also and then we had the housing
boom where more and more people were
able to purchase the houses and
everything was growing this is how the
fayette system works so we at the
beginning stage where it was kind of
tough middle stage which was pretty darn
good for a lot of people and now we're
at the end stage where the system
completely falls apart people
continually charged as much as they
possibly can because the salaries the
wages are declining and what happens is
it hits retail it hits the housing
market it hits food restaurants and
during the 80s the 90s early 2000s we
kept on building
let's open more stores let's keep going
let's you know have the internet sales
let's let's just keep building as much
as we possibly can
that was the build-out phase now we're
in the contraction phase where a lot of
people can't go out and purchase like
they used to they don't have the funds
they don't have the jobs they're not
making the salary that's where we are
today we're at the end of the cycle now
back to the IMF report they're saying
that things are good right now
well really are they a lot of the
countries they have a huge amount of
austerity on the people unemployment is
to continually ticking up yes they they
manipulate the calculations to make it
look good but if you remove all those
manipulative calculations what you
really see is unemployment is very very
high and here in this country they're
saying the unemployment is anywhere from
20 to 22% 23% and a lot of people who've
lost our positions they've got part-time
jobs and you have to remember what they
did was you lost a full-time job got two
part-time jobs it was one part one
full-time job lost two full times gained
even though you're working part-time and
the IMF came out with their financial
stability report they're saying that the
numbers look good the global economic
growth is continually growing and they
said out in the future not too far off
in distance because of Trump's policies
of trade wars tariffs reciprocal taxes
slashing taxes they see problems now
this widening income inequality the IMF
says that this has been exacerbated by
technological advancements and it could
lead to murad of problems down the road
so you really think this is because of
technological advancements or do you
think that there's an income inequality
because basically those insiders those
central bankers those on Wall Street
they all have the inside track and the
rest of the people are sitting here
going what is going on here this is why
the middle class is disappearing this is
why the poor are getting poorer this is
why the 1% is getting wealthier and
they're saying because of the
slashing of taxes because of the trade
wars because of the tariffs we can see
that we're going to have a huge amount
of problems in the future and this is
all being blamed on what Trump has done
up at to this point where he slashed
taxes there's trade Wars and they're
saying as time goes on as we reach 2020
they're projecting out they're gonna see
that things are going to get worse and
worse as time goes on now what they're
trying to tell us is that everything
that Trump is doing is completely wrong
what they were doing you know with
Greece and Cyprus and Italy and France
and you know pushing austerity on the
people making the government's cut and
slash and remove all the jobs and have
the people suffer on the street so their
debt can be paid that is a better
solution remember central bank's they
like to keep countries in limbo they
can't get out of their debt problem but
the debt problem doesn't sink them and
this is what they've been doing forever
the reason why they're coming down on
Trump's plan so hard is because whenever
there's a plan that counters the central
bank's and actually makes the country do
much much better than it really should
be doing under the central bank they
don't like this and I do believe that
Trump will be pushing to get rid of the
central bank I mentioned this many times
before where there's Andrew Jackson
hanging on his wall and Andrew Jackson
got rid of the central bank actually he
campaigned on getting rid of the central
bank and I think eventually once
everything's all said and done if the
plan goes as planned the last step would
be getting rid of the central bank
because again the central bank is the
cause of these problems around the world
and saying every single problem but
putting nations into debt starting wars
and everything else all goes back to the
central bank and there's no reason we
need a private corporation loaning
government's currency with interest at
matched where the people then have to
pay taxes you have to give up your
hard-earned money and give it to the
central bank because that's really where
it's going it's not going to help the
government you're paying the interest on
the debt because the government
continually needs to borrow borrow
because there's no system put into place
to say hey you can't borrow anymore yeah
the debt ceiling is a waste of time I
mean look what they have to do oh yeah
we'll just vote to raise it a little bit
more oh well they've been doing this
forever the checks the system that
should be put into place to say okay we
can't borrow from anyone because there's
no one to borrow from this is what we
have so guess what we can't do that
program we can't do this program it's
almost like your household you're
bringing in a certain amount of money
you know how much money you have and
guess what you can't do these certain
things now if you're given a credit card
well all of a sudden you can do a lot
more but there's interest attached and
your salary is gonna go for it to pay
off that interest on that credit card
and as you keep borrowing you get deeper
and deeper into debt and as time goes on
the situation gets out of hand well this
is what's been happening in this country
for a very long time this is why we're
in the trillions in debt not a million
not a billion but trillions 20 trillion
actually it's a lot higher than that
because if you count the unfunded
liabilities and everything else it's
much much much higher than that and this
is because the government the government
officials who have special interest
groups they don't really care I mean
look they put together a spending bill
of over a trillion dollars I mean where
is this coming from
yeah they're gonna borrow it and then
they're gonna say oh we don't have
enough tax receipts coming in to pay for
the interest on this so we have to keep
the interest for every low and the
interest moves up guess what it's game
over this is why you're not seeing it
happen and if they do continually raise
the interest rates which they're doing
very slowly guess what happens to the
entire system it
Rush's this system is not designed to be
a benefit to the people this system is
designed to benefit the central bank in
every single way because no matter what
happens guess what their debt obligation
doesn't go away the people still owe the
central bank unless of course the
President or someone says you know what
we're just getting rid of this where
we're gonna pay off the original note to
the central bank and we're getting rid
of it and all this debt is made up
anyhow we don't have to pay it but at
this point with the government officials
they're intertwined with the central
bank and I think what Trump is going to
do eventually because he realizes what
is happening here he's a businessman and
there's Patriots behind him looking at
this saying yeah we need to get rid of
the central bank Andrew Jackson saw this
and said yeah we don't need this type of
system the founding fathers warned us of
this and of course in 1913 well that's
when the central bank was once again
brought into the United States under the
Federal Reserve name which made it seem
like it was part of the government and
it was all a ruse to enslave the people
that's really you're a slave in this
system think about it you're working
every day and you're giving a portion of
your hard earned earned work your
currency that you're receiving off to a
central bank you're paying the
government and the government has to pay
back the central bank because there's
interest attached so you're working for
the central bank this is why it's called
a Federal Reserve Note it's why it's not
a US Treasury bill it's a Federal
Reserve Note it's an instrument of debt
so what we're seeing right now is that
the IMF is worried the Fed is worried
because what he's doing right now is
he's pushing to destroy the central bank
economy not the people's economy this is
the central bank's economy and don't get
confused when I do when I say destroy I
don't mean just bring it down
we started I mean get rid of it the
central bank well they'd like to bring
the economy down because they make money
when the economy's up when it's down it
doesn't really make a difference they
want to bring it down so they can
restart it again
and the central bank the way they do it
is they make it seem like they're not
really doing anything to affect the
economy they're bringing the interest
rates up very very slowly everything
looks great and they know what happens
each time they bring the interest rates
up the economy starts to buckle under
the weight things start to go south and
then they start bringing the interest
rates down again but it's a chain
reaction and they know this and by the
time the economy comes down they've been
bringing the interest rates down and
they can say we had nothing to do with
this it wasn't our fault but there might
be something else that brings it down
because there's so many black swans out
there the LIBOR rate is continually
increasing every single month or so and
since the beginning until now since they
brought the rates down it has increased
them what's very interesting about this
is that the US Fed Funds rate the LIBOR
rates they that first of all it stands
for the London interbank offered rate
which is an important benchmark interest
rate that is used for price loans across
the globe when the library library is
low it means that loans are inexpensive
and vice versa and with the US Fed Funds
rate the library eights were cut to
record low levels during the 2008-2009
financial crisis in order to encourage
more borrowing and you know economic
growth and things like that
unfortunately economic booms that are
created via the central bank
manipulation a borrowing course are
typically temporary bubble booms rather
than sustainable organic economic booms
when central banks raise borrowing costs
as an economic cycle matures the growth
driving bubbles pop leading to a bear
market financial crisis and recession
when you look at the library and you
look at the chart you can see the
historic bubbles where they are formed
during those
LIBOR rates and as the rate moves up
guess what happens all of a sudden the
bubble pops and we saw this in the chart
matches up to the 2007-2008 crisis we
see it going back to the dot-com bubble
in 2001 we see it going back to the 1990
to 1991 crisis there I mean each time it
correlates with what has happened with
LIBOR so we're seeing a lot of these
indicators letting us know that problems
are headed our way now what's very
interesting is that there are many
countries now dumping Treasuries China
decided not to purchase anymore they
were dumping we see Japan they are
dumping their Treasuries and Russia the
Central Bank of Russia has sold 3.1
billion in US Treasury bills as of
February reducing its investment in
American debt to the lowest level since
March of last year and they're expecting
to dump even more now the question is
was this part of the plan because we can
see that Trump is working with China
working with with China on the trade
deals and building and creating
everything for the new economy
in the meantime countries are dumping
Treasuries
he's already explaining to the country
into the world that Russia and China
they are basically devaluing their
currency and it looks like he might be
they might be pushing a currency war
where he's going to devalue the dollar
and maybe have the dollar crash because
we know that the central banks they have
to raise interest rates during this
period of time and we know what happens

keep raising it until the economy
buckles under the weight and then they

the library moving up moving up moving
up and we've seen the pattern there
where every time it it is brought to the
lowest point
starts moving up like this the economy's
come down when the Fed raises their
rates during a low interest rate type of

down and it looks like Trump is pushing

now he needs to control the narrative of
when this system comes down any
complaint
neither finger at the central bank
saying listen we have proof we know they

bank
I think they caused this by raising
